item.name: 1655: Habemus Papam
item.comment: Fun little auction game and fairly quick. I liked the different abilities and weightings of the various card groups. One player in our group did say that he pretty much played randomly (and won) though

item.name: 221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
item.comment:
Dug out after many shelf years
Entertaining roll-and-move game, the deduction element seems well done and rewards visiting relevant locations in order
The only issue I perhaps have is how specific to be on the answers - sometimes when you see them at the end (normally after someone else has won!) you realise you had enough to win yourself

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: Plays very quick and so suitable as a filler game. There's a level of tactics here not immediately apparent, also as the game is light there's a lot of social interaction and chatter.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Fun, quick game, lots of variables to defer repetition. Card art is good. Want to play more often and with more players

item.name: 7 Wonders: Manneken Pis
item.comment: Not a great wonder but easy to obtain and variety is better

item.name: Advanced Heroquest
item.comment: Never really played this much, seemed unnecessarily complicated for a board game and we'd typically move straight onto a 'full' rpg. Nice pieces tho

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Lots of choices in this game, different paths to victory, tight rules set. Played well with 3 to 5. 24/8 Increasing in score, this game is a real hit in our group, looks daunting to explain but actually is quite easy to learn and see how it all interacts. Definite advantage to have played before and you can be susceptible to being out of it early and struggling for the game (but, conversely we've seen players come from the back of the pack and challenge at the end too).

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: Enjoyed this in a "lots to think about" way. It's a challenging and absorbing game, certainly I'll look at the reprint tho I liked how this version was laid out. Obviously a wealth of supporting material out there, I just wonder if it's a game that would see a lot of play in our group.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Barbados / St. Lucia
item.comment: Map plays well and quickly
item.wishlistcomment: Keep an eye out for a copy

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Mostly solo games so far but I'm really happy with it, the solo option is a real plus - I can't remember any game I've played so frequently after opening. The multi player version brings a different tempo and challenge to the game and overall it scratches a nice itch. Rich in theme, looks to be almost endlessly replayable especially multi player.
09/08 Upping the rating, I like this game, a lot and am keen to play it. As an added bonus it's one of the games Agnieszka will request - a solid 10
06/09 This game continues to draw us in with many plays. What's amazing is that no matter how much we play the game seems to always reach rounds 8 and beyond quicker than we expect - cries of "already?" and "I have so much to do" are usual

item.name: Agricola Z-Deck
item.comment: Adds a little to the game, worth including once you've played a few games with the E deck

item.name: Agricola: Farmers of the Moor
item.comment: A truly great expansion, takes an already great game and changes the gameplay just enough to provide a fresh challenge - does everything an expansion should do rather than just being more of 'x'. Looks to add even more longevity to a favourite game

item.name: Agricola: Ö-Deck
item.comment: Feel like these cards really work well with the game

item.name: Agricola: Through the Seasons
item.comment: Only used in the solo game so far; seems to be a little unbalancing especially in some of the action spaces and bonuses on offer. Be interesting to see how it works when there's competition for spaces.

item.name: Air Show
item.comment: Sort of interesting when playing but fairly unmemorable

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment:
Simple rules set and good quality pieces (although we substitute poker chips for the flimsy paper money). The game goes by pleasantly enough and it all hangs togethere well enough but I don't feel the need to own the game (too many already? well yes but that doesn't stop me adding plenty of others. For some reason this one doesn't quite light the spark)
Jan12 with this on sale at Amazon.de for a very good price I gave in

item.name: Aliens
item.comment: Come on - it's Aliens! Haven't played for a long time, but most games were solo - at which it excelled

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: The cube tower really works, introducing just enough randomisation into each round. The game plays nice and quickly, simple to teach and with varying strategies. All in all an enjoyable experience

item.name: Antike
item.comment: Really enjoyed this, my first introduction to a rondel game. It plays really smoothly and quickly and the turns come round fast. I'm particularly in favour of the multiple paths to victory

item.name: Arena Maximus
item.comment: Fun little race game, the ability to attack each other and the track hazards keep it interesting and entertaining.

item.name: The Ark of the Covenant
item.comment: Nice twist on Carcassonne and good blend of regular and H&G. The Ark adds another concept to the game-play

item.name: Asara
item.comment: Only 2p so far Looks really nice all laid out. Gameplay is quite interesting due to the mechanism of having to follow suit when hiring. Identifying a suit you're deep in means you can lock another player out of options whilst also driving the urgency to get into an area

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment:
The solo game isn't as rewarding as Agricola, perhaps because the show differs from how the multi game plays, but it's still good for learning the game and getting a feel of how the cards interact.
In multiplayer this game shines and a 2P game is quite different to a 4P - in the latter you really have to watch who you choose as your partner.
Both our 4P games have run long but never felt long, I can see this game being played a lot

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: Fun little 'controlled' bingo-ish game that I'd play again

item.name: Autoscooter
item.comment: Not a bad game, v well produced and fun to look at. Some tweaks to the collisions might be in order - completing your turn even if fwd progress isn't finished, just to avoid those situations where you can't move fwd at all. Not sure about the advanced scoring, might be too powerful and prone to swings since there isn't really the scope to target the player (tokens) you want

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment: Enjoyable little race game that seems to avoid the problem of a leader being able to play anything you do when trying to catch up. Presentation is good and rules are nice and simple

item.name: The Awful Green Things From Outer Space
item.comment: I have the old plastic 'zip-loc' box version, but I guess they all play the same. A fun,light nostalgia game (my brother and I used to play lots growing up), silly too

item.name: Bakschisch
item.comment: It was a nice enough game and fun but I couldn't see myself playing it often nor requesting it

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: The rules looked a little much for a simple card game but after an initial "finding our way" game this proved an instant hit with everyone, moreso than I thought it would be. Plenty of requests to play again and everyone found it to be fun.

item.name: BANG! Dodge City
item.comment: Adds more characters and cards to the mix which is good. Not sure about all the green border cards yet as some seem to just add complications but all in all a worthy addition to the base game

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: Sufficiently different to M44 in how you play, looking forward to getting the 'full impression' once Lore is added

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: Flawed gameplay, but the theme makes up for it. We can live with the many pages of errata as it always turns out a fun, tense game

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: Mostly played 2 player, but also introduced to my parents and they love it. Colourful and nice to look at but with deeper gameplay than may first seem apparent

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: It's Blokus and it's portable - if you like the base game(s), you'll like this. It's also more confrontational than 4 player Blokus as the middle ground is contended quicker

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: Plays differently to regular Blokus, feels like a smaller area and the more central start points lead to quicker confrontation

item.name: Blue Max
item.comment: Quality card pieces with great illustrations. A holdover from school days. Can sometimes become a bit aimless with experienced players and characters as you can't always get enough shots in to get a result

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
I wasn't initially entirely sold on it, it's fun I just didn't expect it to have any long term appeal for me. However it's so easy to play and a popular choice amongst our mixed group which sees it brought out more often and subsequent games have seen me enjoy it a lot more. very interactive and it can turn spiteful (in a good, gaming way)
27/09/08 I still like the game but I'm beginning to feel it runs a little long for the gameplay it offers

item.name: Britannia
item.comment: Plays great with 4, too messy to re-sort the pieces for other numbers. 'Like Risk but better' there's a game here

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: Plays quickly and offers several interesting choices. The multi purpose cards can be agonizing at times as you want to use them so many different ways

item.name: Bucket King 3D
item.comment: Crazy dexterity game, gorgeously produced and just played full of laughter and oohs and ahhhs

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: With a 'full house' of 6 players this party game is a lot of fun; silly, loud and plenty of take-that opportunities.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Bought after finding this site - my entry into a world of games and variety. Brilliant entry game, I've introduced non-gamers with this, given it as gifts. Always a winner, simple yet varied in that the same gameplay won't always work. 10/12/07 Been playing this a lot more of late (at work), draws a lot of attention from people passing by and we have people asking to play, thus upping the rating

item.name: Carcassonne: Abbey & Mayor
item.comment: Thrown in the new tiles already, the extra pieces will be added (or not) as tastes and players demand

item.name: Carcassonne: Cult, Siege and Creativity
item.comment: Another cheap, small expansion, maybe 8 Cathar tiles are too many (as they benefit farmers) with the sole Cathar expansion. On the other hand doubling the number of Cult tiles makes that rule more likely to occur which is good

item.name: Carcassonne: Die Katharer
item.comment: A neat little addition, gives a bit of "screwage" to the game, on the other hand the ability to feed the besiegers makes farms even more attractive and, hence, fought over

item.name: Carcassonne: Die Kultstätte
item.comment: An extra variety and not so many tiles as to prolong the game. The number of times a Cult tile will come out next to a Temple is few and so this is an expansion that makes little impression Added mine to my Wheel of Fortune set

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: Essential expansion - the big meeples proide for more varied stealing, the Cathedrals (especially) and the Inns give a good way to hinder other players. Also a good number of extra tiles

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 2 – Traders & Builders
item.comment: Typically we add the extra tiles, often the pig and much less, the goods tiles. I find the goods a bit too much of a swing in the overall points (although I see what the point of them is in encouraging closure of other players cities). The advantage of Carc is it's flexible enough to just play with the ingredients you fancy that game.

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: The first 'work game' that got people hooked on playing board games at lunch. Also very popular as a 2 player game with my g/f

item.name: Carcassonne: King & Scout
item.comment: I use the extra tiles but not the extra rules, but so cheap it's worth picking up

item.name: Carcassonne: Neues Land
item.comment: Wasn't a huge hit with my other half as she prefers regular Carc. I'd like to try it again, I liked the idea of cycling your meeples more, but maybe that flies in the face of 'traditional' Carc too much?

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment: Nice 2 player option, have to change your way of thinking from regular Carc given that it allows so many unmatched features

item.name: Carcassonne: The Mini Expansion
item.comment: Adds some more tiles to the mix, some more useful than others, to give extra possibilities. I've just thrown the tiles in the main bag as standard

item.name: Carcassonne: The River
item.comment: Don't really like the layout the river leads to, just play occasionally for variety

item.name: Carcassonne: The River II
item.comment: Much like River I. Not an essential Carc expansion but cheap enough to pick up for when you want a bit of variety

item.name: Carcassonne: Wheel of Fortune
item.comment:
Interesting one this, obviously it's more Carcassonne at heart and your appetitie for this will depend on that for the base game. However the wheel comes into play for scoring a lot more than I expected and provides a viable choice. The wheel segments also all trigger and even the Plague, while initially seeming a negative can be used to extract a Meeple from a trapped or unpromising place. Overall I'd say scoring is up across the game.
Originally I intended to throw it into the main set, but I feel this would greatly dilute the wheel tiles (frequency) and the game certainly stands on its own, so I think I'll leave it as is. I expected it to be just the tiles from the basic start set but there's some pleasing additions in terms of city ends. A welcome addition to the Carcassonne family

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment: Rating for this is tricky since the experience is far more than the game. I suggest forget about trying to win (although if playing for points 10 is probably too long) and just enjoy the crudeness of the cards and the laughs that ensue

item.name: Cards Against Humanity: Third Expansion
item.comment: It's more of the same but that's no bad thing and the blank cards are a bonus

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Probably too easy (at least out of the box) but a lot of fun and the components are well produced

item.name: Catan
item.comment: A huge fave, always a lot of interaction at the table

item.name: Catan Card Game
item.comment: A new fave, really involving game, plays quick yet is absorbing.

item.name: Catan Dice Game
item.comment: Entertaining fun, quick to play but offers some choices. Playable for all the family too

item.name: The Cave
item.comment: Gameplay is a little fiddly with all the tokens. many of which are quite small. The tiles are atmospheric and the player board a nice twist

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: Solo plays only so far A lot of familiar territory to Agricola but enough differences to warrant both. This one almost has too many choices (in terms of action spaces/buildings) so it can be a bit overwhelming at first. Contents and production are excellent (even the cover-up cards for some round - nice touch). Not a 10 as the solo game has a fixed set-up (I realise I could randomise it but assume the designer put it in as such for a valid reason) and I think that limits the replayability, also doesn't have the progressive solo game that made Agricola's solo play so absorbing

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: A strong game in the worker-placement area. Multiple paths to victory of course, easy to pick up and the game length has some variability to it

item.name: Chess
item.comment: It's a classic sure, for gameplay I'd rate it higher but it's not something I often want to play

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: Looks absolutely great and plays really well too. We have fun with this one, a very sociable game and always close at the end.

item.name: Coal Baron
item.comment: Nice little variant on WP being able to reuse spaces at a higher cost The mine lift is pure gimmick but a lot of fun. Gameplay presents a lot of challenging choices each round but the game is easy to pick up

item.name: Coda
item.comment: Nice little variation on Mastermind or similar games, played with 3P and some good stuff to think about

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: Lots of bluffing and tactical play, took a while to get to grips with the rules and how they play out on an initial readthrough.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: A solid game, there's a lot of decisions to be made (and thus the game can be a little subject to AP) and you never have enough actions to do them all. Certainly rewards clear long term planning. Very high production values typical of DoW. Very well received in our games group. 11/7 Been playing this again recently and we've been pleasantly surprised how quickly it plays once people know the rules. The dignitaries maybe don't move as much as they could - especially in a 3 player game

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment: Not as visually appealing as others in the range but I like the tweaks such as flanking, unit coherence etc - wish I could get it to the table more

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment: My grandfather taught me this and I'll always be thankful for that. An absorbing, entertaining game - the luck of the draw against recognising the possibilties

item.name: Cuba
item.comment:
Beautiful game to look at, it's going to need a few plays to learn the buildings and how the game interacts but the promise is there. Length is about right and, sure, it has elements of other games but this makes it easier to teach/learn.
July 09 Been playing this a bit more recently and getting to grips with the tactics but I just feel like it will never be preferred to its sister games such as Stone Age, Pillars & Caylus.

item.name: D-Day Dice
item.comment: Only played solo so far. Game is well produced with solid play boards, though the cards are possibly a little small. Rules are introduced in a step by step manner which is often a good idea. There's a lot going on especially to manage the luck of the dice

item.name: D-Day Dice: Flare Pouch
item.comment: Small expansion, doesn't add a lot nor overcomplicate things

item.name: Defenders of the Realm
item.comment: All 2P games but a lot of fun. Like most co-ops of this nature that I've played the game can swing between "in the bag" and "no hope left" in a single turn - and that's what is fun, especially when you still manage to pull off a victry at the end

item.name: Descent / Runebound / Runewars Figure: Tobin Farslayer
item.comment: Seems very powerful

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: The introductory adventure was heavily weighted in favour of the adventurers but the others have been much more even. Satisfies that 'rpg urge' without the lengths of a campaign (though on some adventures it's a close run thing!). Quality pieces, entertaining game

item.name: Descent: The Well of Darkness
item.comment: Haven't tried the new adventures but all the rest - rules, characters, monsters etc - are great additions to the base set.

item.name: Diamant
item.comment: A game that brings lots of laughter, playable by 8(!) with no real down time or increase in game length. Easily teachable and well presented.

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: The hidden objectives all seem pretty even within our group and most games have finished with one or two other players feeling they could have won on the next round, if only... Lovely production values and the theme all seems well worked in

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: A fun party game, easily playable by most people. The cards have enough variety on them to allow for a lot of interpretation (and prevent staleness) but it's amazing how often how many suitable cards are provided making for tricky choices. Only played with 4P so far and looking forward to trying with more

item.name: Dixit 3
item.comment: More cards, more choice, more fun

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: What's not to love about Dixit? What's not to love about more choices?

item.name: Drako
item.comment: Challenging enough play though I wonder if it could get a little samey. Also the fact that it's only 2 players will restrict the times it comes out. Theme is clearly king here and it comes through well, all the pieces and board are very well produced and there's a very real feeling of loss as the Dwarves are whittled down

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: Very light game that doesn't offer a lot of choices

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: Enjoyed the first game, suspect it rewards frequent players as "character combos" can be tried and re-used; but it never seems to get back onto the table

item.name: DungeonQuest
item.comment: Just doesn't have the same feel of fun as it once did - to be fair up until only a few years ago. Good gameplay, was novel at the time, I think there's just things I'd rather be playing

item.name: Dungeonquest: Catacombs
item.comment: Catacombs doesn't really add much to be honest

item.name: Dungeonquest: Heroes
item.comment: Improves the base game although a couple of the characters are over-complicated

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: I'm not sure how much this really captures the D&D (4th ed?) experience, since, at least in our plays the plan is to keep drawing monsters and avoid Encounters; thus the game becomes more a case of rushing thru a dungeon, reather than cautious advances etc. However it all works and it's fun. The game is a lot of fun, scales well across a number of players and has been a hit for all. I do have a question as to it's long term appeal, since the monsters etc become a bit familiar (which, given the rushed nature of the game, means they can become quite abbreviated when they're revealed). Having said that, there is a goodly number of adventures presented in the book and of couree, all the piece are top notch

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: A good game, I can see there's an awful lot of game here - it's having the time to play it. I could see the rating increase

item.name: Eggs of Ostrich
item.comment: Quite a spiteful little game (a good thing), simple in design and not as obvious as a first play may have you think

item.name: Eketorp
item.comment: Only one play but it seems to me to have a rich get richer angle to it, difficult to mount a comeback if you have an initial poor start - at least with 6 players. Having said that I think I was the only one of our play who felt like this. Cute Viking meeples (Veeples?) tho'. I'd try it again, but wouldn't suggest it

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: Although I can see the game is prone to AP as there's a lot to consider, this was a lot of fun. Easy enough to teach and you can see people coming to grasp with the possible strategies. A decent amount of conflict and interaction.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: Good little game, quick and smooth to play, the 7 turns whistled by. I suspect it plays better with 4 and 5 where the increased competition will also lead to more areas being opened

item.name: Entdecker: Exploring New Horizons
item.comment: Fun game, easy to pick up, though the rules, as presented, seemed a bit over complicated. When we played we later worked out that any one of us could have won the game during the last round, despite a large seeming gap in the scores - that's a big plus for me

item.name: Evo
item.comment: An entertaining game (at the least you can have fun pimping your dino!) but I felt it dragged a little long for what it was. I'd play it again, but I probably wouldn't push for it to be brought out.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment:
Feel like the game is sweeter with more players (even tho 4 provides the 2nd most counters) as the chaos factor increases, also may benefit from a short timer just to keep things rolling along and more prone to mistakes. Simple to play and even if you're eliminated most people don't mind as it's fun
8/5/10 Considering taking one move card out to make the fatal round come quicker. Also too many people are getting in range of the exit in the first round so I guess we should play more against each other

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: A lot of fun - the theme fits well with the co-op style of play. Really good solid components also

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: Doesn't appeal as much as Pandemic. On the plus side the random tile layout and variable islands provide replay on the downside it doesn't generate as much emotion as Pandemic which holds a better story/causes more anguish

item.name: Formula Dé
item.comment: Admittedly on only one play, seemed a little 'scripted' - once one player was in the lead their decisions seemed obvious and attempts by the rest to take risks and thus catch up proved fruitless. Perhaps multi-lap races, or, if you have them, a season of different tracks would give it more appeal (I'm not a huge fan of F1 and this may also have had a bearing).

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: A nice light WP game, easy to explain and the roles flow into one another meaning everyone can compete from the get-go. Looks a really nice game when laid out (even the box insert is themed) and the addition of 3 expansions or variants in the box is a nice touch

item.name: Fungi
item.comment: Nice little 2 player that opens up in possibilities as you play it

item.name: The Fury of Dracula
item.comment: This used to be an old favourite, but boy can it drag on! Eventually the price on eBay was too much to resist and I sold it, might pick up the FFG new version

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment: Doesn't seem to have the long game problem that the original did, whilst a little fiddly in places the game has high production values and plays smoothly. Very enjoyable.

item.name: Geistesblitz
item.comment: Manic game play and quick enough to fit in a couple of games. Plays upto 8 and no language dependency which are both bonuses

item.name: German Railways
item.comment:
Hard to decide about this one - initially I thought the weighted draft mechanic of the turn order was a really neat idea. Having been (a little) and seen (a lot) people on the end of it I'm not so sure - A game where you go and make a round of coffees for all the players and not miss much? not so sure that's going to be a regular table topper.
The share ownerships and mechanics of the game are nice and each railroad having it's own ability looks to be an interesting twist, I'm just not convinced it's enough of one to overcome the long gaps. Also, is piggybacking to victory really that satisfying?

item.name: Get Bit! Deluxe Tin Edition
item.comment: Not the game I hoped it would be in truth. It just falls a bit flat - and I've played it with a couple of different groups by now - and even I struggle to maintain enthusiasm for it in the face of others

item.name: God's Playground
item.comment: I want to like this but it does seem a bit over-complicated. The fact it only sits 3 players also keeps it off the table

item.name: Gold Mine
item.comment: Very luck dependant - dice heavy and random treasure tiles. Plenty of player on player screwage though; this does have the effect of lengthening the game, which, if you're already out of the running isn't pleasant. The components, especially the miners and gold pieces are really well produced

item.name: Granada
item.comment:
Offers some difference to Alhambra but not enough to warrant buying both.
May be open to rich get richer syndrome but would need more plays to be certain.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: A new favourite, the game plays well, easy enough to explain and pick up. Gameplay tends to be competitive throughout, often with scoring swings at the end.

item.name: Guardians
item.comment: Beautiful art but it never really got played much, maybe if I had the time?

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: An interesting twist on co-ops that perhaps takes some getting used to. I wonder how long the scoring will hold up given there's no winning target as such just a banded system

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: I'd heard mixed reviews about this one and, as much as I loved Agricola, hesitated on this - shame, I thought it was excellent once I got to play it. I can see it would take a while with many players/new players but the game is superb

item.name: Hawaii
item.comment: One of those that sounds harder in the rules explanation than it really is. The game flows well and hangs together; the varied board makes for a lot of varied gameplay as it alters the relative currency of the in game items. As you'd expect all the components are well produced

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: A fun lite table top rpg, recently re-acquired as I thought my wife might like it and my friends and I remembered it fondly

item.name: Hex Hex
item.comment: silliness incarnate - a good closer at the end of the evening when we're all wiped from gaming and full of food & drink

item.name: Hex Hex Next
item.comment: Adds more cards and silliness (but also complexity, in terms of card interaction and timing) to the base game. Well worth it with the right group - one prepared to embrace the chaotic nature of the game and go aong with it

item.name: Hey! That's My Fish! Deluxe
item.comment: bought this for our 5 yr old nephew and he really loves it. Lots of fun, quick to play and attractive to look at.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: A thinking game, quality pieces, tactile to play. Like the GIPF games meets that quiet reflective mood of game.

item.name: The Hobbit: The Defeat of Smaug
item.comment: A bit of fun at first, but really little more than a kids game

item.name: Hol's der Geier
item.comment: Fun game to play, quick, easy enough that it can be a family game too. Have Hol's der Geier version

item.name: Hotel Samoa
item.comment: I really liked this a lot - possibly more than then game play alone would warrant. But that's the beauty of games - woth the right people, and/or the right mood the experience is more than the simple facts of the game might suggest. The tabletalk here was what made the game, full of dodgy national steretyping and humerous comments. The game itself played fast and the components are really well produced

item.name: Hunting Party
item.comment: It's nice that it's optimised for 3 (not sure it's even worth playing with different); although that will limit the opportunities to play. Not sure how representative of a first game ours was, the Prophecy seemed to be uncovered very quickly and then it became a race to acquire the necessary skills - we were expecting more of a discovery game a la Cluedo or Mystery of the Abbey. Some of the characters seem to have 'niggly' powers that while not gamebreakers just prove as irritants, but again, maybe that was just the game we had. High quality components and the fantasy theme means it appeals to a few of our group.

item.name: If Wishes Were Fishes!
item.comment: There's a lot more to this game than the cute pictures and rubber worms may lead you to believe. In just a couple of games you saw people start to look to manipulating the rubbish bin and setting up plays

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: Certainly an interesting set of mechanics and although a bit to get around at first it all seemed to come together well.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: Immense fun, already started using it as an introductory game. Attractive to look at and absorbing game play

item.name: Ingenious: Travel Edition
item.comment: Prefer the fuller edition as the game is always enjoyable with multiple players and scales well. But, as a travel version this works very well

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: Easy family friendly game, quick and light to play and plenty of laughs

item.name: K2
item.comment:
Very nice game, quick to explain and get hold of but a lot of depth to the things you have to manage.
At first I thought the fixed board would be a limiting factor and lead to over familiarity in approach before I realised that everything else is variable and that's where the variety will come in.
A very tight game where you have to adapt your approach to other players and the turn of the cards - and even then your success isn't guaranteed

item.name: Kapitän Wackelpudding
item.comment: It's a kids game, sure but entertaining (especially when alcohol is added) enough for adults. Can drag a bit towards the end

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Such a simple to understand,yet enthralling game. Our first game was all newbies and it flowed evenly and quickly with everyone competing. This game can get nasty as resources get tight, which is great, though I imagine it could leave some players being frustrated if they get blocked out too often. There are correcting options though and every game has always felt like everyone's competing (even allowing for the hidden yet trackable resources and VPs)

item.name: Kiki Ricky
item.comment: Fun childrens game easily playable by younger children, really needs 4 to make it work though

item.name: Kill Doctor Lucky
item.comment:
The latest version looks great. The game itself is open to variable length of play and I suspect most games go through the deck before a murder happens.
The sort of game that needs to be played with good humour and be in the moment and the large number of players and ease of game play is a plus

item.name: King of Siam
item.comment: It was ok but too dry for my tastes, even reading the flavour intro afterwards didn't really change that. I quite like the mechanism of trying to influence one area but that the act of that reduced your chances but with so many other choices I couldn't see myself playing this again.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Variable boards and variable win conditions look to provide longevity and certainly mean you can't easily approach each game with a set plan.

item.name: Kolejka
item.comment: More gameplay than it looks to have at first, this is more than just a tie-in game. Only played with Poles, many of whom it brings back memories for and that undoubtedly adds to the gameplay, there's some real take that aspects to play. Downside would be a slight tendency to jam up in the end game but that might be our gameplay approach

item.name: Kung Fu 2100
item.comment: My rating is how I remember it - if I were to set it up again, who knows? but for now it sits and reminds me of my youth

item.name: Las Vegas
item.comment: Quick playing dice game so fairly luck dependant but fun. Definitely worth using the dummy player in all games

item.name: Last Night on Earth: Growing Hunger
item.comment: Good new characters, lots of optional additional rules, just what you want from an expansion

item.name: Last Night On Earth: Hero Pack One Expansion
item.originalname: Last Night on Earth: Hero Pack 1
item.comment: Maybe not the best set of characters but I'm always in favour of more choice in games like this

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment: An instant hit, lot of fun, laughter and the theme is so rich. Quick to learn and I can see this hitting the table a lot. The scaleability to 6 players is a real plus too.

item.name: Level X
item.comment: Despite being nominally a childrens game this plays well with adults, in fact with only adults I could see it being quite cut-throat. Played in a mix of young and old it works well, the children are entertained and the adults not driven mad with boredom. The game is quick to play and well presented, chuncky cardboard and hefty dice As a dice driven game it is of course luck dependant but, manageable luck - you can nearly always make something with 4 dice.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment:
The game looks beautiful no doubt about that.
A few too many options and interactions between the gameplay elements for me making it daunting for the first (and 2nd, 3rd?) time player. Then within each are you have yet more options (50 cards - really? how long to even know what's there never mind assess the interaction?). The game requires a lot of planning and there's a frustration of I want to do x, then y then z and I only get to do one thing this turn but it seems slow (maybe that's the other players, but it feels like the game).
I think this would shine when everyone playing has 5 or so games under their belt but I just don't see that ever happening for me and I'm not sure I want to go through the journey of getting there.
Glad to have tried it and I'd play it again but removed from my want to buy list

item.name: Loco!
item.comment: Fun little filler, but maybe not as enjoyable as the others I'd consider comparable (No Thanks, 6 Nimmt etc). Simple enough to teach and play, portable - I can see this being taken overseas with me (and the language independance is a plus). One thing and I know it shouldn't bother me but it does - but who thought to create an inner box that doesn't hold all the chips?

item.name: Looping Louie
item.comment: A fun quick, kids game but it draws adults in as well. Plenty of laughs, a good opener or closer to an evenings gaming.

item.name: Loot
item.comment: A nice light card game, quick to play and easy to get a few hands in. Doesn't offer anything particularly new but worth playing at the start or end of a night

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment:
The theme doesn't really come through despite the licence and the attempts (quest names etc) to tie it in.
What it is though is a very good WP game. Easy to learn - certainly for our group who have played a lot of these but I'm sure also for newcomers as it's very instinctive - and it all clicks together well. Finite number of rounds make it surprisingly quick, I like the staged addition of an extra worker at mid game also - just as spaces are typically getting scarce.
The production is gorgeous - all the board and card art, but also the smaller things like how all the pieces fit perfectly on the board. As for the inlay - either it's perfect or annoying having to fit everything into space each time

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: Downloaded this from XBLA and can't believe I've missed this game for so long (I certainly knew about it). Enough to think about in a game, quick to play. I could see this making a good gift also.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment:
What a lot of gameplay and tactics crammed into such a small deck of cards!
Our plays have been full of groans and "If only"s

item.name: Lucky Loop
item.comment: Plays a bit simply, wasn't a hit with Agnieszka, although I'd give it a go. My favourite mechanic in the game was pooling the bonus tokens

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: Entertaining light game that doesn't outstay it's welcome. All the players are involved all the time which makes for a lot of table chatter

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: Got back into this on XBLA and was quickly reminded how solid the game is when the cards available are self contained. Before I knew it, I was buying starter decks on ebay...the slippery slide begins

item.name: Magnum Sal
item.comment: Really enjoyed this, all the components just hang together nicely. It seems simple but there are "just enough" decisions. Because coins are your VPs you're always trading now for the future. One thing that would be nice (for increased longevity) were if there were more chambers for each level than the minimum just so you can never be sure what will show up.

item.name: Mali Powstańcy: Warszawa 1944
item.comment: Only played the Basic game so far but very enjoyable. The game plays fast, all the mechanics hang together - especially the use of the movement cards to gain an advantage in turn order. I was surprised by how well the use of locations played out as well. It's a curious trait of th egame that even though you're competing for orders you're still pleased when a fellow player delivers as it prevents the Germans gaining an advantage

item.name: Maori
item.comment: Pleasant game without ever really being anything special. Also worth noting that the translated rules really change how it is played (not for the better, I believe)

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Immense fun, works well as a sole player game as well. Wish it could have more table time, but being 2P it tends to be brought out while we wait for other players to arrive

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment: Lavishly produced as you'd imagine. I think 3-4 would be the sweet spot, plenty of competition and not too long (even our 3 player game took a couple of hours) Good fun and a fine theme

item.name: Metro
item.comment:
Like this a lot, very quick and easy to play, can introduce this to gamers and non-gamers alike as it's so easy to pick up and teach, quick to play also.
Sep 09, down from 7.5 to 7. It's a good introduction game (and portable to boot) but there are games I'd prefer to play

item.name: Mondo
item.comment: Very easy to pick up and play (from 6+ we've found) and you can see that more plays quickly pay off in terms of being able to score well. A lot of variety in one box with extra rules that are easy to introduce in small steps

item.name: Monopoly: X-Men
item.comment: well it's x men :-) but it's monopoly :-(

item.name: Monty Python Fluxx
item.comment: Not sure about games like this, they don't offer enough fun for the length and often outstay their welcome

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: Silly fun, but it always seems to take so much longer than it should. Can be a little wearing

item.name: Munchkin 2: Unnatural Axe
item.comment: More of the same

item.name: Munchkin 3: Clerical Errors
item.comment: And some more

item.name: Munchkin Blender
item.comment: A munchkin too far - I like the humour in the game (being an old time roleplayer) but it draggggs so much

item.name: Musketeers
item.comment: Nice little card game, some take that aspect to it and a bit of bluffing

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment: An entertaining social game, we ham up the idea of being monks, often a nice light-hearted closer to the evening

item.name: Na Grunwald: rycerze króla Jagiełły
item.comment: I thought this was great, Worker Placements are a fave and this is right up there for that feeling of just wanting one more option. Lots of unusual stuff here, the semi co-operative aspect of fending off the Teutons (or, selling out your country for your own gain - how many WPs have that sort of integration of theme?); the allocation of workers with the boss being worth more but only being able to top up in certain circumstances. The theme really fits well, tying in to the history and you have the feeling of carrying out the tasks the game sets you. It's a shame this won't get more attention, but for me it could well be a hidden gem

item.name: Nations
item.comment: Probably prone to playing a little long as there are a lot of choices each time but an intriguing game

item.name: Naval War
item.comment: An old battered copy, shows how much it's been used. Still fun, simple as anything, guaranteed to become "attack the leader" and lots and lots of stories behind it - classic

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: Well produced, plays quickly, the sides look even.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Duel
item.comment: Both new armies add something different

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: Just not sure about this yet. The rules are a dogs dinner and it may be shelved until a definitive FAQ is produced. The game plays a little randomly snd it wasn't a big hit with our usual group who all preferred reguar Carc. Looks very nice tho

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: Entertaining and light hearted, plays nice and quickly with a few decisions. I like the random board set up and the secret mission cards as they combine to generate a differing game each time.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: An instant hit, fun, simple and very quick to play, nice and social too. I keep a copy in my desk at work

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: This is a new game finding a lot of early favour in our group. Constant decision making, never enough resources to do what you want. It's a very quick game too and the fixed time limit of 9 turns rattles along, initially daunting to look at when learning but easy to pick up. I can see this being brought out often.

item.name: Odin's Ravens
item.comment: This is a neat little game, brought out as filler or when we only have a little time to game.

item.name: Oregon
item.comment: Overlooked this game when it came out as the reviews I read didn't really sell it. Picked up as part of the Works cheap deals and it has quickly found favour. A nice little light medium game, quick to explain but with just enough depth to draw you back. Weak theme that can be overlooked since the game has Cowboy Meeples

item.name: Der Palast von Alhambra
item.comment: 'Late' coming to this one but I'm really enjoying it. Lots of options of victories and one of those games where an opponent always seems to take your tile or card just before you were going to. Think 3 or 4 players might be the sweet spot but also enjoyable with 2. It's a relatively quick game also

item.name: Die Paläste von Carrara
item.comment: Basic game so far Plays very quickly and offers some good choices in that time

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: The game is very easy to teach, plays well and fast, the tension building up as the cubes mount and you race against the game. Solid production values, I guess the cards could wear from the shuffling. Like all co-op games could be prone to a dominant player running the group but due to the ease of play I think most people can contribute and thus hold their own.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: The extra components are all winners - the petrie dishes proving very popular. In all if you like if you like Pandemic, you'll like this since it does what an expansion should do - offer more of the original game coupled with new twists.

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment: well it's fun if you've a few minutes

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment:
Absolutely loving this. You really get drawn into the game story (if you're even the least bit willing and I assume you are if the game appealed to you at all) filling in gaps and fleshing out the narrative.
The cards are a good quality and thick although I can see that they will chip over time from the constant handling and shuffling

item.name: Perpetual Commotion
item.comment: I really like this, reminiscent of card games we used to play at school. Absolute silliness, no down time, 'insults' fly as thick and fast as the cards

item.name: Pictionary
item.comment: Not being able to draw makes this more fun! party games may not be played as much but they're always funny when they are

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: I like games where you always wish you had one more action/pawn/turn and this fits the bill ideally, gorgeous to look at and very engaging to play - a new favourite

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
item.comment: Didn't really grab me and time and many games later I can't remember anything about the game

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
item.comment: Like the new options available and all of the cards fit in well, not sure they're all equally useful but that's the luck of the game. Also the enhanced numbers in each deck add a nice degree of unpredictability. A worthy addition to the base game, makes it better (fixes the Master Builder some people have an issue with), but for me the best change is not being able to rely on certain crafters etc coming out. I think that increases the games longevity

item.name: Pit
item.comment: Odd, insane fun. An evening closer

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: Great fun, playable by anyone, the more players the better. Everything in the game is high quality now I want the expansions

item.name: Pizza Box Football
item.comment: Looking good on the early plays

item.name: Poker
item.comment: An involving game, best played with players of roughly even ability.

item.name: Potato Man
item.comment: A gaming group fave! Brings lots of laughs and is a great little closer. There's some good tactics that come out in games of this

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: Don't be put off by the box (which looks like a game my parents would have played as kids), there's a really good game here. Parts that appeal to me are the varied map so games are different in play and the random selection of plants all meaning each game is different. Expandable as well there's an awful amount of game play here before it could ever get stale.As to the game itself, it's finely balanced for 3 plus players, easy to learn, close and competitive - a real winner

item.name: Power Grid: Benelux/Central Europe
item.comment:
I'm not experienced enough a PG player to feel I could make a good compare & contrast with other maps, however for me, this map was enjoyable and competitive. Everyone (5P) started in different countries but were quickly drawn into contesting cities.
I hoped having the Central Europe map might encourage my wife to play more as she finds the boards quite drab (alas it didn't).

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: Runs a little long and looks susceptible to runaway leader (tho' more plays will tell if this is true), a closer board than Talisman but less player interaction as PvP is only worthwhile during the endgame. Doesn't seem to have the unbalanced items of that game tho'

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: A great game, plays well 2-5. Bit of a learning curve and experience gives an advantage but it's easy to pick up, flows logically and draws players in - a classic game 2009 - Been playing this more as a 2 player game and it holds up very well, I feel like we should implement the expansion tiles soon

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Games like this are entertaining enough though I wouldn't pull them out by choice as I feel there are better options. Still, with a few players and the ability to hinder each other it is fun

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment:
Fun abstract game easily introduceable to non gamers.
Good chunky pieces add to the game experience

item.name: Qwixx
item.comment: Offers some interesting choices to mitigate the luck of rolling dice. Players are involved throughout

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
Probably needs a few plays to get the hang of the game and when to do what. My first auction game, interesting but not necessarily a feeling of "I must get that"
Been playing this a lot on iphone and enjoying it so I picked up the boardgame

item.name: Railroad Tycoon: The Boardgame
item.comment:
A new hit in the group, a lot of rules to get to grips with initially but it all flows nicely, still getting to grips with the tactics and such. Gorgeous to look at. Board can be a bit spaced, especially with fewer players, still waiting for a healthy, competitive 5 or 6 player game.
Oct 11 Having just played this and Steam in a week, RT has lost a little of it's shine. Too easy for the rich to get richer. When I play again I will definitely use the recommended variant (standard in the other maps) and lay all the routes out at the start

item.name: Rails of Europe
item.comment: Tighter than the US board making it more suitable for 3 or 4 players and so more likely to be played. Many different ways to victory means replayability.

item.name: Railways of England and Wales
item.comment: The best of the RT boards, really close and tight which makes it competitive. The open route bonuses (carried over from Europe) are a better idea meaning they don't sudenly pop out and lead to a big swing. Production values on this version are bit below the others, the colours are a bit washed out, although the blue/black clash is resolved.

item.name: Rat Hot
item.comment: Intriguing little two player. Offers some nice challenges and is deeper than you might think - there's enough to keep an eye on as you play

item.name: Rattus
item.comment:
Well produced game, nice thick role cards, since they're handled a lot are advantageous.
Quick to play means you can immediately follow up with another game. The game itself plays quickly and is easy to explain.
Only negative is that the 6 supplied roles lead to a lack of variety, sure the expansion fixes that but it feels like it was planned to sell like that and double dip the market

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn
item.comment:
Fun game, we like the fantasy theme, being old role players. Quirky cards and you can ham up the game too. Will consider the expansion as I could see this being the first or last game of many evenings.
Would prefer it if the cards in each deck had different functions rather than generally being rethemed but (mostly) identical

item.name: Return of the Heroes
item.comment: Ditch the impenetrable rule book and get Novas guide off the Geek, then play and enjoy yourself! A fun game, just about right on the time stakes and doesn't outstay it's welcome like some of it's cousins. Having said that I'm also left feeling that while games like Talisman overdid the variety of characters/monsters/equipment etc that this could benefit from just a slightly bigger pool for variety.

item.name: Rhino Hero
item.comment: Quick playing fun game. Cards are very well produced

item.name: Risk
item.comment: Ugh, a boring, mundane game I was more than happy to the back of. No variety

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: Fiendishly difficult, but so challenging and just worms into you - everything hangs together well and it is one of those games that leaves you thinking after about what you could do next time.

item.name: Robo Rally: Armed and Dangerous
item.comment: More of the same - with a group prepared to play loose and fast it's fine, but just one slow decider can drag the game down

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: A fun theme, games always seem to run too long and players end up just wanting it to be over

item.name: RoboRally: Crash and Burn
item.comment: See roborally

item.name: RoboRally: Grand Prix
item.comment: See roborally

item.name: RoboRally: Radioactive
item.comment: See roborally

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: Good quality components, played it a lot on i phone first and the RL experience is just as good (though you have to be aware of the differences between single player and multi)

item.name: Runebound (First Edition)
item.comment: A little slow to play but it's fun. Sure it's "the new Talisman" but that's ok since I'm not sure I want to play the old one anymore (Now have 2nd edition)

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: This takes a long time - we'll definitely use the Doomtrack rules next time. Also suffers from runaway leader problems, but the theme is very rich and I like how many of the cards tie together adding to the story

item.name: Die Säulen von Venedig
item.comment: This game plays well and finished very close, the key seemed to be timing the finish to when you'd be in front (not are) which introduced a lot of tension late in the game. It looks nice when set up and was a hit with everyone who played.

item.name: Scene It? Movie
item.comment: A simple party game, I love films so it's a chance to chat movies etc. Good to play with non-gamers (and then bring out one of "my" games and ambush them!)

item.name: Scene It? Music
item.comment: Prefer the movie version but even the music questions aren't too 'specialist' so it involves everyone - but, as always, a single player can dominate.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: Can get my family to play this

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: With a group prepared to play along with the theme this is a lot of fun. Also it looks great when set out

item.name: Shear Panic!
item.comment: Fiddly rule-set that the cute pieces don't overcome, only played 2P.

item.name: Sorry! Sliders
item.comment: Lot of fun, plays really smoothlybought to entertain my nephew but will work with me too

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: It'll be interesting to see how this holds up in the long run but for now it's a quick hit. Initially Aga & Stani weren't keen (it's space, it's Czech ;-) ) but by the end of the first game they were laughing and by the end of the 2nd it was being asked for next week. Production of the game is very good, the theme is rich and it's a lot of fun

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment:
Very hard to win this game, even solo.
Cards are a decent thickness and should last. Nice and portable game

item.name: Spellfire
item.comment: Used to play this a lot but can't even sell the cards on ebay now

item.name: Spite
item.comment: I don't normally grade games after one play, but once was enough. Sheer torture

item.name: Star Fluxx
item.comment: I'm not really a fan of Fluxx games, they're "ok" and generally good for a few laughs while you're playing them but, even as fillers, they're passing. This does have good references though and the game seemed better than the Monty Python version

item.name: Starship Catan
item.comment:
A good complement to the Catan card game, but with a richer theme
Nov 13 When I first played this it was round a friends house, having played more recently it went very long using the rules as written. We played again since and used the traditional Catan rules of everything produces on a matching dice roll which made it better but still dropping it from a previously inflated 8

item.name: Statis Pro Football
item.comment: This used to get so much solo play, a great game, if slightly long. But when you're in the mood for some football - it's the best

item.name: Steam: Rails to Riches
item.comment: Really liked this, the rules are clean, pieces of good quality. The gameplay was very smooth (4 pl, 90 min including rules explanation) and nicely competitive due to the tightness of the map. Can see this improving in score as I play more and I already want more maps
item.wishlistcomment: tried AOS and quite liked it, this new version might well find a home with me

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: Gorgeous production - the art is beautiful and I like that all the resources are shaped differently and appropriately which adds to the feel. The game plays smoothly and hangs together well, certainly enough familiar concepts to allow it to be taught to regular gamers easily, although the concepts are worked in well and refreshingly enough to keep it different from other games in the genre. Refer to the geek Rules discussion, as written they're a mess, amazing since they look well laid out

item.name: Stone Age Erweiterung: Die neuen Hütten
item.comment: The new huts all bring in added value and different tactics, recommended

item.name: Strozzi
item.comment: Wish I'd picked this up at the Works now, well worth £3.99 Nice quick auction game that sounds far drier and uninvolving on the back of the box than the gameplay gives you.

item.name: Super Munchkin
item.comment: Same as regular Munchkin, but possibly even longer

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment:
Fun, fast, good artwork on the cards. Easy to explain and teach for gamers and I would assume non-gamers alike.
Play is quick, such that even if you get a bad draw of cards another game can easily be played, besides over 3 rounds it all evens out.
Ideal filler game

item.name: Taboo
item.comment: Silliness abounds, one of those games that just has stories attached to it

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: Gorgeous components, simple to play and just enough depth

item.name: Talisman
item.comment:
The gameplay is in the stories and events within the game (which is a simple, often frustrating roll and move). If you're prepared to go along with the twists and turns of the game and accept a Curse of the Hag with the same grace as a Runesword then it's a fun game.
However it does go overlong, especially with players unprepared to risk all by building up their characters to some superhuman level. The expansions are generally worthwhile additions providing an increase in choice and adventure (often tho, for a commensurate increase in play time)
At the end of the day there are games I'd now rather play but it remains on hand if we fancy a blast of nostalgia

item.name: The Talisman Dungeon
item.comment: Some good new characters, the Dungeon itself offers a nice alternative to the traditional route to winning

item.name: Talisman Expansion Set
item.comment: Significant additions to the game (new characters, adventure cards, spells) without further complications or play length - recommended to own

item.name: Talisman: The Adventure
item.comment: Worthwhile addition in terms of adventure cards and characters

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: Very nice game to look at, really catches the eye. Involving to play and clearer to understand than some of the initial reviews (that I read) on here made out. I suspect it rewards repeat play quite strongly.

item.name: Tension: The Crazy Naming Game
item.comment: Average party game, offers fun in groups, however dented by some odd answers and also no easy way to acknowledge all the answers being shouted out whilst also recording them - every round we played ended up with "we said that one" when the missing answers were revealed - only ok if everyone is prepared to play fair

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: We started with a 2 player Simple Game and the feeling was that it flew by too quickly, the game never really started, but we put that down to it not being the full game. Later played a 4 player Simple Game and it really came into it's own, far superior and already an involving game. I think as we move onto the Full Game the 2 player version will be viable.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: I really like it, the work crowd not so much, unfortunately echoed by a couple of my home crowd (I'm at a loss as to why). A lot to consider when playing and a very social game

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Although the concepts look similar (connect towns to earn points), this requires a completely different train of thought :-)to Ticket to Ride. The bonus counters mean careful route planning is invaluable and you feel as if you can never afford to waste a go

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Very good intro game, still regularly played, best with 4 or 5

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment: Both maps are fun. The team map especially provides for a new way to play that really changes your game- just what I want from an expansion, more of the same but tweaked to a new experience.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 – The Heart of Africa
item.comment: Probably the most vicious of the maps so far, an awful lot of unintentional blocking takes place which depending upon your attitude for that will affect your enjoyment of the map. The bonus scoring cards offer another interesting twist

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 4 – Nederland
item.comment: An interesting variant on Ticket, the tolls and all tracks open regardless of player numbers make things entertaining

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europa 1912
item.comment:
Just as with the 1910 expansions for base Ticker, reinvigirates an old favourite by mixing up the ticket deck and preventing over-familiarisation.
Haven't yet tried the warehouses and depots

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: Very popular with everyone - especially at work during the lunch hour. The 'closeness' of the map encourages more confrontation which is a good thing

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Märklin
item.comment: As others have said tension is prevalent here - apparently in 2player games I play really frantically? The set-up/pack away time is longer due to the merchandise counters so we tend to play twice each time (at least), but maybe that's a good thing? ;-) This may actually end up being my favourite of the series. Definitely the 'gamers' version

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment:
Limited numbers means it'll see the table less but this is a fun board. Combining aspects of many of the previous releases provides for a bit of a rules muddle. I can see why the frequent need for engines drives the alternate options (3 of any card) poviding something to do with all those cards you collect. However the tickets seem to have a really good mix between smaller, complimentary ones and the bigger routes.
Not strictly recommended for any but completionists, but I also wouldn't say don't buy this, it's sufficiently different to warrant a place in your collection.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Switzerland
item.comment:
Component quality is quite poor (thin cards, board lifts, semi-useless insert) which does affect your play and that's a shame as this is a quality game in play terms. Tight with 2 or 3 players it provides a nice alternative to regular TtR
Full credit to DoW for addressing the card quality issue and providing free replacements.
The game can often be won by getting a good base network and then drawing tickets, especially if the country tickets come up

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
item.comment: Didn't really take, all the players were regular TtR players and this elicited lots of blank looks as we went through the rules and the general feeling at the end was "rather play the board game". I'd give it a go again, maybe with just 2. I'm not sure about how this is marketed (travel TtR), I find the board game very portable once out of it's box - regularly take 2 or 3 boards, 1 deck of cards and the trains in a backpack

item.name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: Brings new life to an old[er] favourite, makes me want to play it a lot more again

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: We're one of those groups who can't relate the rules to the game, because it doesn't get played a lot we always have to re-read the rules and that keeps the game in the cupboard

item.name: Tongiaki
item.comment: Still a little undecided about this one. Plays simply enough with a lot of screwage but then also you feel a little out of control quite often. The open, simple scoring, also means you can easily tell when to end the game and if you're in a good position

item.name: Torres
item.comment: Played once with 3 players - deeper than it looks but I think of the 3 of us I preferred it. Nice quality pieces too.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment: Tried a 3 player co-op game and it was a lot of fun, probably a bit easy (against the Horseman) but everyone enjoyed themselves. I suspect competitive play may be where the game finds it's strength again. Looking forward to bringing this out again.

item.name: Tri-Ominos
item.comment: Fun enough, it's nice to have games at my parents house for when we visit

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: The Lord of the Rings Movie Trilogy Collector's Edition
item.comment: Answer "Aragorn" to everything and you should do alright

item.name: Ugg-Tect
item.comment: Hilarious party game and who doesn't like bashing their friends on the head with inflatable clubs (whether warranted in-game or not)?

item.name: Vampire: The Eternal Struggle
item.comment: Nice art, enjoyable theme , just don't really play ccgs anymore

item.name: The Viking Game
item.comment: I have a nice crafted set, it's an entertaining game with obvious relationships to chess and so easier to draw a non-gamer in.

item.name: Vikings
item.comment: Really liked this game (only played the basic version). It plays quickly and (like Stone Age) has that feel of "I'd play that again right away. Probably takes a game or two to establish the tactics but even a new player can be competitive. May 09 Now playing the Advanced game (no auctions) regularly which is the preferred version. Aug 09 After a few 4 player games, I do wonder if this is one of those games that would suit the system where players start on different points based on turn order - Since there's always 6 rounds you end up with Hobson's choice in too many rounds

item.name: Village
item.comment: A really nice example of a WP game. Sounds more complicated than it is when you explain it, but once underway everyone always seems to grasp it. The game has some nice mechanics and varied paths to victory, definte keeper,

item.name: Village: Customer Expansion
item.comment: Nothing game changing about these, just nice to have. Thrown in with the main game, I wouldn't really miss them if they weren't there but I'd be unlikely to take them out either. At a cheap price they're good to have to add to the game

item.name: Villannex
item.comment: A really interesting idea but there's probably a little too much to consider, especially in higher player counts. You'd get to the point where you're thinking "he'll expect me to do this so I should do that, but he'll know, but, but, ah i'll play anything" Also the scoring seemed quite swingy, we had some rounds won 6-5-5 and others went 16-10 (-12)

item.name: Vinci
item.comment: I like this a lot - variable abilities (as represented by the combination of civilization tiles) prevent the Risk (the game to which this would draw the most - unfair IMO - comparison)syndrome of same tactics each game. Scales well for different numbers of players.

item.name: Wallenstein (first edition)
item.comment: I really enjoyed this, comparitively quick for the gameplay involved, lots of decisions. Just need to get it on the table again!

item.name: Warlock
item.comment: Growing up we used to play this a lot, nowadays there's so many better options out there

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment: Gorgeously (over?) produced and it started well though, in our first game, we found it started well and then bogged down as we'd not saved enough 2 item recipes so as to be able to cycle the cards. This hung the game somewhat and it became how quickly could 3 of us end it before the 1 player with any small recipes get any more points - which did mean the other 2 were in something of a kingmaking position (I was currently in the lead and so happy to see it end). Bit chaotic in the first game, I wonder if it would be more useful in the menu cards actually included the ingredients to give players some idea of what to choose - our first game was a bit of 'luck of the draw' as we had no idea of the make-up etc

item.name: We Didn't Playtest This Either
item.comment: I think the silliness appealed to me more than the others I can see it being something to bring out after a few drinks or throwing it in a bag to take away with you, but, overall, limited appeal

item.name: Wind River
item.comment: Good game with a depth not immediately apparent. Well produced pieces and thematically strong (AFAIK). Enjoyed it, easy to play and teach, I do wonder though if it would last prolonged play.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment:
Hard to see why this is out print, surely there's always a market for games like this?
Quick to play, decisions and interactions abound, all in all a fun game

item.name: Wordrop
item.comment: My parents have a copy and it provides a nice game if we're over there visiting. Doesn't have the scope of Scrabble, you're going to be primarily scoring on short words.

item.name: World Without End
item.comment: Much nastier than Pillars with every turn a struggle to survive - only to be undone by the event cards. But it's fun and every game is close.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: The game was a little too subject to cards coming out and introducing rules tho that was probably a result of the hurried rules run through. It plays well enough, quick and well presented pieces

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: Similar to Dvonn, I can see the quality of the game here it's being in the mood (quiet, reflective) to play it

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: Requires a certain amount of knowledge of the effects of each option but plays smoothly.

item.name: Zbuduj swoje miasto
item.comment: Quick little game, your play is very much determined by making the best of the hand you draw rather than pursuing a tactic.

item.name: Ziegen Kriegen
item.comment: I really liked this little filler game, it plays smoothly, has a little bit of 'take that' to it

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Very pretty components and a fun game to boot with enough going on to satisfy
